description: From stop +‎ -ed. In some senses, the adjective follows from the verb; in others, it may derive directly from the noun stop.

adjectives.description: stopped (comparative more stopped, superlative most stopped)

entries.meaning: (of a vehicle) Not moving, but not properly parked or berthed; said also of the occupants of such a vehicle.
examples: We were stopped for more than three hours!
They passed a stopped car on the side of the road, but realized there was nothing they could do to help.

entries.meaning: (more generally) In the state resulting from having stopped.
examples: A stopped clock is right twice a day.

entries.meaning: (of a pipe) Having a stop; being closed at one end.
(of a plant) In a well-pruned state.
(phonetics) Made by complete closure of the organs in the mouth; said of certain consonants such as b, d, p, and t.
examples: þ was first voiced and then stopped , becoming d

entries.meaning: simple past tense and past participle of stop
